summary: Her.
title: Her.
body:
Pairing: Peter Parker x Reader

Word Count: 1,271

Summary: You go into work after your eventful weekend getting over your grocery shopping experience thinking that you’d have a normal Monday at work. Oh how you wish it was normal.

A Note: i told myself that i didn’t need to put this out today. here i am. putting it out. today. it’s fucking 4 in the afternoon and i’m out here with a sequel already. i’m attached to this series. there will be a third part, thank @spider-slutt for giving me inspiration to write this out, please don’t try to hate me too much.

Warnings: There’s no real warnings yet, but there’s mentions of a gun near the end of the piece. Part One Part Three Part Four Part Five AO3

It was an early Monday morning when you walked into The Square Diner.

Cold air hung in the dining area where the tables were, due to the sudden snow that decided to hit New York City.

You loved it.

You waved to some of the regulars who were happily sipping at coffee while they looked at their menus, still bundled up in their winter coats and scarves.

If only you were so lucky.

You made it to the small back room and started to work on tugging off the warmth and security of your jacket, hanging it on one of the free hooks, along with your bag you’d brought your college work with you for your break.

A normal, average, everyday Monday.

You came back out in your uniform, already genuinely debating on pulling your coat back on and praying your boss didn’t see you wearing it.

Ignoring the idea you’re quick to grab a small waist apron that was already armed with various pens and a server pad nestled in the semi-deep front pockets, ready to get to work.

You’re the only other server besides Janice that’s there this morning, the cooks happily conversing in the back.

The atmosphere is light.

Your morning slowly gets busier, serving a few regulars and newcomers, trying extremely hard not to curse out to any man who just so happened to try and flirt with you.

The audacity.

By the late morning, your section of the diner was almost empty, your usual party of three coming in before sitting at their usual booth.

You sent them a wide smile as you made your way to their table, pen and server pad at the ready.

“Welcome back to The Square Diner, you guys. The usual?”

Click. Shift.

“We’ll actually start today off with some coffee, if that’s okay, Y/N,” Matt said kindly, turning his head in the general direction where you stood. 

You were quick to scribble on the server pad before smiling, drawing a small symbol at the top of the ticket that you insisted on using whenever the Lawyers of Hell’s Kitchen came in.

“Of course! I’ll be back with some mugs.”

You were quick to get the three mugs and place them in front of Karen, Matt, and Foggy before filling them up three-quarters of the way before carefully sliding the creamer cups and sugar up a bit closer to their hands so Matt didn’t have to feel around or get directed by Karen and Foggy too much.

“Creamer’s on your left, sugar’s closer to the right. I’ll check back in with you in a bit to see if you’re wanting anything else, alright?” You said kindly, your smile growing as they thank you as if you’ve just given them water after walking through a desert.

You’re in the middle of placing the coffee pot on the dock when the bell to the diner rang and someone sat at the breakfast bar, that was also sadly your turn to serve until your break.

“Hi, welcome to The Square Diner, what can I get you?” You said as you turned around, only to almost freeze in your place.

It was her. The girl Peter was with that night.

Who said that this could happen? In all the places of New York-

“Hello! Uh, I’ll just take a coffee for right now, thank you.”

Inhale. Force Smile. Turn.

You grabbed a mug from the small rack in the corner of the counter behind the bar, quick to place it in front of her as she read the menu and grab the coffee pot to fill it three-quarters of the way.

“Let me know if I can get you anything, alright?” You forced your smile to look more authentic.

The girl smiled and nodded as she looked at the menu.

You let your smile fall quickly after you placed the pot back on the dock and went back to Karen, Matt, and Foggy’s booth.

“Have we decided on what to order for your late breakfast?” You questioned, letting a small smile come up as you held your serving pad and pen in hand again.

Click. Shift. Clear throat.

You were quick to write down their orders and relay them to the cooks before you were practically forced to turn your attention to her.

“Have you decided on anything, ma’am?” You asked.

Wow, she really brings out the customer service voice out of you.

“Oh, um, yeah, I’d like..” She started, trailing off slightly as you quickly got your pad ready to write her order on a new page before she spoke up, looking at your face. “You look familiar..”

Oh no. No, no no no.

“I work here as often as I can between classes-” You offered before she cut you off, her face lighting up.

“You’re the girl that Peter ran after in the store the other night!” She exclaimed, seeming genuinely happy to actually meet you. You wish you felt the same, but something in you just wouldn’t let that happen.

“Oh- Uh, yeah. Hi.”

Shift. Click. Inhale. Force Wider Smile.

“You’re- you’re Y/N right? Peter’s friend?”

A friend? Friend?

“Yeah, I am,” You gritted out with your best tone possible that wouldn’t get you fired. You moved your pen to your hand that held the pad and held it out. “And you are?”

“Emily.” Her hand was weirdly soft and not at all cold in your hand as you briefly shook hands.

“Nice to meet you, Emily. Glad to put a name to the face.”

You wish it was your face that was kissed at the store that night.

“Same here! I’ll tell you my order super quick and I’ll let you get your orders, I’m so sorry for keeping you!”

You didn’t get what she meant until you glanced over your shoulder to see the food for the only booth you have. Oh.

Quickly you wrote her order and slid it to the cooks before piling the hot plates on your arms with ease, moving over gracefully to the booth the group sat at.

You really wish waitressing was an olympic sport, you’d get the gold.

You laid the dishes in front of Foggy, Karen, and Matt respectively and asked if they needed anything else.

After that point, your day got a little easier.

The Lawyers of Hell’s Kitchen left right as the diner picked up for the lunch rush, leaving you a nice tip between the three, and plans to swing by their office to get a look at some cases you could go and try to help them with.

Emily was seeming to be nice, which made you swallow your pride and try to push back that she’s your ex’s new girl.

She seemed sweet, kinda like the Snickers you devoured during your show’s rerun that night.

But your mind wouldn’t leave it at that. You kept replaying how she and Peter had kissed at the store and your sadness came back that you shook off over 48 hours ago.

It was agitating.

You didn’t have any choice to run. No choice to hide from it.

It really made you want to swan dive into the oil of the deep fryer in the kitchen during your break.

However, that was avoided.

Barely.

You were talking with one of the cooks, trying to get yourself into higher spirits when you were both on your breaks, Emily still at the breakfast bar as she ate her food.

It was all silent.

Until you heard what sounded like a gun cocking, and someone screaming as if they were in a horror film, about to get murdered.

You grabbed a mug from the small rack in the corner of the counter behind the bar, quick to place it in front of her as she read the menu and grab the coffee pot to fill it three-quarters of the way.

“Let me know if I can get you anything, alright?” You forced your smile to look more authentic.

The girl smiled and nodded as she looked at the menu.

You let your smile fall quickly after you placed the pot back on the dock and went back to Karen, Matt, and Foggy’s booth.

“Have we decided on what to order for your late breakfast?” You questioned, letting a small smile come up as you held your serving pad and pen in hand again.

Click. Shift. Clear throat.

You were quick to write down their orders and relay them to the cooks before you were practically forced to turn your attention to her.

“Have you decided on anything, ma’am?” You asked.

Wow, she really brings out the customer service voice out of you.

“Oh, um, yeah, I’d like..” She started, trailing off slightly as you quickly got your pad ready to write her order on a new page before she spoke up, looking at your face. “You look familiar..”

Oh no. No, no no no.

“I work here as often as I can between classes-” You offered before she cut you off, her face lighting up.

“You’re the girl that Peter ran after in the store the other night!” She exclaimed, seeming genuinely happy to actually meet you. You wish you felt the same, but something in you just wouldn’t let that happen.

“Oh- Uh, yeah. Hi.”

Shift. Click. Inhale. Force Wider Smile.

“You’re- you’re Y/N right? Peter’s friend?”

A friend? Friend?

“Yeah, I am,” You gritted out with your best tone possible that wouldn’t get you fired. You moved your pen to your hand that held the pad and held it out. “And you are?”

“Emily.” Her hand was weirdly soft and not at all cold in your hand as you briefly shook hands.

“Nice to meet you, Emily. Glad to put a name to the face.”

You wish it was your face that was kissed at the store that night.

“Same here! I’ll tell you my order super quick and I’ll let you get your orders, I’m so sorry for keeping you!”

You didn’t get what she meant until you glanced over your shoulder to see the food for the only booth you have. Oh.

Quickly you wrote her order and slid it to the cooks before piling the hot plates on your arms with ease, moving over gracefully to the booth the group sat at.

You really wish waitressing was an olympic sport, you’d get the gold.

You laid the dishes in front of Foggy, Karen, and Matt respectively and asked if they needed anything else.

After that point, your day got a little easier.

The Lawyers of Hell’s Kitchen left right as the diner picked up for the lunch rush, leaving you a nice tip between the three, and plans to swing by their office to get a look at some cases you could go and try to help them with.

Emily was seeming to be nice, which made you swallow your pride and try to push back that she’s your ex’s new girl.

She seemed sweet, kinda like the Snickers you devoured during your show’s rerun that night.

But your mind wouldn’t leave it at that. You kept replaying how she and Peter had kissed at the store and your sadness came back that you shook off over 48 hours ago.

It was agitating.

You didn’t have any choice to run. No choice to hide from it.

It really made you want to swan dive into the oil of the deep fryer in the kitchen during your break.

However, that was avoided.

Barely.

You were talking with one of the cooks, trying to get yourself into higher spirits when you were both on your breaks, Emily still at the breakfast bar as she ate her food.

It was all silent.

Until you heard what sounded like a gun cocking, and someone screaming as if they were in a horror film, about to get murdered.

body:
‘till death do us part | p.p

summary: “Peter knew in his deepest sense that things would be alright. Even if he stuttered the entire way through his vows, and dropped the ring and fumbled over the steps down the stairs. At the end of it all they would still be lovesick messes and exchange breathless laughter between curved-lip kisses.”

warnings : angst, mentions of injuries, a little language? (the rest is fluff I promise)

I take you

Peter had never, in his wildest, most surreal dreams imagined being here today. With the pristine light of early morning rays filtering through ornately designed windows, arcing above their heads and set in aged but intricately carved stone. A sea of familiar, beaming faces sitting in the pews. Composed of not-quite blood relatives but family all the same; all of them alight with inexplicable joy on a day nearly everyone had been betting on since Peter’s sophomore year at Midtown when he bumped into the best thing to ever happen to him-and spilled her physics homework all over the hall.

He was nervous, to say the least. His clammy palms and bouncing heels were proof enough. Even Ned was beginning to get a bit exasperated at how frequently Peter would ask the time or try to run a hand through his carefully done hair,promptly ruining all the hard work May had done that morning to try and tame his wild curls.

Peter knew in his deepest sense that things would be alright. Even if he stuttered the entire way through his vows, and dropped the ring and fumbled over the steps down the stairs. At the end of it all they would still be lovesick messes and exchange breathless laughter between curved-lip kisses.

That didn’t stop him from nearly jumping out of his tux when the massive chapel doors heave open with a labored groan. The sound seems to reverberate through the hollows of his lungs, filling them to the brim with a familiar too-full ache. That’s how he always feels when she’s around. Too full. As if there’s only so much space in his body available to contain the amount of love and adoration he holds for her. Something so immeasurable and indescribable couldn’t so easily be held in the confines of Peter’s heart.

So it presses against the walls of his lungs and curves of his ribs, making his jaw go slack and eyes water when they land on her figure at the foot of the walkway. He can barely get enough oxygen in his lungs to laugh at himself, feeling a bit unsteady on his own two feet as he drinks in the image of her donned in white and glowing with the radiance of-

to have and to hold

“Sirius,” she states quietly, Peter’s gaze following the tip of her finger to the pinprick of light only fully visible through the massive telescope they’d both been stealing glances from (along with a few directed towards each other) throughout the night.

“Like, from Harry Potter?” She let out a soft laugh at his inquiry, the sound making Peter’s heart thump a bit faster and his lips press together in a sheepish smile. It was a nice sound to hear. Mellow, sincere, and just bubbly enough to coax a small, breathless snicker from himself as well.

He noticed just before she ducked her head down in a bashful smile that her eyes seemed to glint with a different kind of light than they did during the hustle and bustle of the school days. A bit more real,a bit more raw. He supposed something about having the whole of the galaxy mapped out before you did that to a person. But maybe he just saw the reflection of Canopus in the sea of her irises.

Sure, her heart would skip a beat nearly every time she caught Peter staring at her after she’d come back from peering through the telescope. And she felt the world wobble beneath her feet a bit when his hand brushed against hers while adjusting the focus. But at the moment they were simply a pair of over-enthusiastic teens gawking at the intricately woven constellations hung up well above the light pollution of a never-sleeping city.

“Exactly,” She lifts her head back up, a faint ghost of a smile still visible in the curve of her cheeks. “It’s the brightest one we’ve found yet. Just along Orion’s belt,” she traces out the contours of the asterism, fixating once again on the star in question.

Peter nods, unable to keep the smile from his face as she continues to muse about the various shapes, sizes, and stories drawn across the night sky. She looked nothing short of breathtaking like this. Peter couldn’t get enough of the wonderstruck brilliance that she radiated while explaining every small detail and facet of the celestial wonders beheld to him. He never dreamt he’d be close enough to a star to feel the nuclear fusion tingling at his fingertips.

from this day forward

She had promised herself she wouldn’t. She knew it was ridiculous and completely naive of her to be indulging in ideas like that. She knew better and she’d be lying if she said it wasn’t getting rather irritating trying to run from what she felt for Peter.

She hadn’t seen it coming. It was supposed to be just another normal day. Normal being a relative term considering her life had been turned upside down since that first night with Peter at the observatory almost seven months ago.

It was impossibly wonderful and painfully new for her. Having somebody as thoughtful, understanding, and genuine as Peter wasn’t something she was used to. And while he was nothing short of amazing to her, and she adored every minute she got to spend with him-there was a sense of unshakable vulnerability that she still had yet to fully accept.

So when he texted her amidst the hectic buzz of her Monday morning with a new picture of that dawn’s sunrise-she found herself typing out a response without a second thought. The grin was still on her face as she pressed send, not even realizing that she’d just taken a massive leap and would soon be feeling the effects of a nosedive into the deep end.

“Oh my god,” she breathed,heart skipping a beat as she read the text a second, third, and fourth time.

‘God,I love you,Parker,’

“Shit, Shit, Shit,” she muttered under her breath, tugging a hand through her barely brushed mass of bedhead and shoving the phone across the kitchen counter before beginning to pace wildly about the room. Her stomach was churning and head was spinning with all the possibilities of how this could end- none of them being positive of course.

After what feels like ages of stumbling about the chilled tile, she braved a glance back at her phone.Her heart dropped straight to her socks.

'Read: 6:15’

She felt her throat begin to close up and top row of teeth come down harshly on her bottom lip, gnawing vainly to try and diffuse the terror spreading through her veins like ice water. Just when she thought she might be sick from the wait, a loud crash from her front balcony sends the young girl straight into a whole other panic.

Her breath hitched and eyes went wide,fixating on the figure strewn across the concrete floor, leg entangled in a lawn chair and kicking helplessly to try and escape it.

“What the fu-” she can’t finish her sentence before she’s at the pair of glass doors and Peter’s flushed face lifted to meet her gaze, still lowered onto the floor where he’s splayed out and ensnared by her mother’s favorite lounging seat. Finally,he managed to struggle free from the confines and onto his feet, chest heaving and hair still fluffed about in a clearly slept on fashion.

“Peter,” She exclaimed, absolutely awestruck as she pulled back the door to stare at him with parted lips and furrowed brows. “How did you even get here I live two blocks away-” Peter didn’t even let her finish the sentence before letting his backpack slip off his shoulders and feet carry him straight to her incredulous person.

She didn’t have the time to register him lifting his hands to cup her face before their lips had already met, his own gentle yet insistent as he held her as close as possible. He could hear both of their hearts hammering against the cage of their ribs and feel her feather light touches shock his skin like lightning bolts. He was so caught up in the moment that he almost forgot to breathe until his lungs began to burn.

Nothing but the heavy gasps of the pair filled the space between them for a moment, eyes wide and searching eachother’s for any sign of just what the hell might be going on. “I wanted to tell you in person,” he murmured, cheeks burning and hands lowering back to her own. They were shaking furiously as he took hold of her palms, which began to tremble as well as soon as they connected.

“What?” She asked, completely dumbfounded and having forgotten just what she was so distraught about as soon as Peter had kissed her. He pressed his lips together like he always did when he’s anxious,working the bottom one between his teeth as Peter attempted to pluck up the courage to get the words past the hollow of his throat.

“I,” He inhaled, running his thumbs over the backs of her knuckles in a desperate effort to ground himself. “I love you too,” his eyes only dare lift up to hers for a moment, flickering around her face to try and gather any sign of recognition that he could. When her eyes start to gloss over, he thinks the worst.

“Oh god I didn’t mean to-” She practically throws herself onto him, arms wrapping around his neck as she pulls his frame flush against her own. Peter can feel her shoulders shake with a small, watered down laugh, hands gripping the fabric of his hoodie like a lifeline. He quickly wraps his arms around her middle to return the gesture. Peter’s heart began to even out its pace, and they both just stood there for a moment, trying to figure out how they got so lucky.

She hadn’t been sure before. Whether things with Peter would work or not. Whether she could keep counting the days until things inevitably crashed and burned for the pair of them. But at the moment, all she needed was his arms round her waist and nose against her temple, soft utterances of the phrase passing freely between the both of them.

When she lifted her head from his shoulder, her eyes catch on the deep red and blue fabric spilling from the top of Peter’s backpack, which still laid carelessly dropped on her balcony. She pulled back a moment,brows furrowed and lips curled just the slightest. “Peter?” She fought down a light laugh, her boyfriend stirring from his moonstruck daze only to appreciate her smile.

“Yeah?”

“Why do you have a morphsuit in your backpack?”

for better or for worse

“Do you even care?” the words clawed past the minuscule passage of her throat and tore through her teeth like bullets from the barrel of a gun. They hit Peter head on. Straight in the hollow of his chest where he presumed his heart was intended to reside. But at the moment it had just felt like somebody replaced it with a bundle of barbed wire; prodding and poking at all the bruises littered across his chest and scraping the sides of his lungs so air could only leak out like that from a punctured balloon.

The wounds hidden beneath this sweatshirt felt measly in comparison to seeing her like that. All pursed lips and red rimmed eyes. Her whitened knuckles were curled around the massive binder clutched close to her chest, where he was meant to be. Instead it felt like they were universes apart, Peter just now coming to the realization that there was no oxygen in the vast emptiness of space.

He sputtered, absolutely perturbed that she would even ask a question like that. Of course he cared. He cared so much that he felt he might burst at the seams some days. But maybe today it was more than a feeling. He could sense himself crumbling as he struggled to get the words out, falling short when her eyes began to water. “What do you mean?!Of course I care about you-”

“Not me-this isn’t about me,Peter,” she said sharply, words having an effect all too similar to the shrapnel that had gotten lodged in his stomach the night before. “This is about you- you throwing yourself into danger at the smallest sign of it and not even thinking about what could happen. You could have-” her voice was the one to fail her that time, splintering beneath the pressure in her lungs and dropping to the scuffed tile floor in shards.

For the first time since he’d met her, the thought crosses Peter’s mind that maybe it would have been better if he hadn’t.

for richer or for poorer

“Peter, oh my god I was just kidding you really don’t have to,” she could barely contain her giggles as she braced one hand on his hunched shoulder and the other on the smudged glass of the arcade game window. Peter found this all the more distracting, and only slightly irritating since her laugh and gentle touch threw off his skill completely. So of course, whenever he tilted his head to share a lopsided smile with her, the machine instantly whirred with a sickenly familiar sound to remind him he’d run out of time.

His face fell into a defeated frown, her own still aglow in the neon lights as she tried to coax him to try out another game with her. But Peter Parker was a stubborn little shit when it came to making his girlfriend happy. So if he had to take out a loan to get that damn Spider-Man plushie, you’d best believe he would.

Without a single moment’s hesitation, Peter took her hand in his and dragged the pair of them back to the token machine with a twenty curled in his other palm. “Peter,” she tried to suppress her laughter long enough to get him to reconsider spending his life savings on a rigged claw machine. Needless to say-it did not work.

Within thirty seconds they were practically sprinting back across the funky printed carpet to the games, since Peter was completely sure that if they waited a moment longer that somebody would come steal that toy along with his girlfriend as well.

Eleven tries and eleven defeats later, she finally managed to get Peter to step away from his newfound nemesis and quite possibly the toughest criminal he’d faced in all of Queens. “Why don’t you let me give it a try?” She wrapped her arms around his waist, peering over his shoulder into the pile of stuffed animals with an amused smirk still digging into her cheeks. With a sheepish smile, Peter plucked his last pair of tokens from his pocket. He slipped them into the coin slot before swapping positions with her and settling one of his hands atop hers that had gripped the toggle and button.

“You don’t get to take the credit for my win just because you held my hand,Parker,” She taunted lightly, trying not to let the feeling on his chin rested atop her head and warm chest pressed against her back get the best of her. She almost dropped the claw accidentally when it rumbled with a soft chuckle, Peter watching on eagerly as she guided it to the perfect spot.

“yes! oh my god!” She fell back into his grip with a grin on her face and laughter bubbling from her lungs. Peter stared in complete shock as the claw dropped the small plush down the hatch with supernatural ease. He reluctantly released her from his arms to let her crouch down and collect the prize, lips parted and eyes the size of saucers.

“I can’t believe that,” Peter shook his head lightly, still smiling enough to let her know she hadn’t completely demolished his pride with her immaculate claw machine prowess. She just continued to laugh, using one hand to hold her newest treasure and the other to link with Peter’s.

“You ready for lunch?Unless you went broke trying to free Spider-Man Junior here, that is,” her eyes twinkled and Peter flushed lightly, the shade deepening when he fished through his pockets and came up empty. “Oh my god you actually did,” she declared, snickering helplessly as she fell into Peter and kissed his heated cheek affectionately while he fumbled for an explanation.

“I’m so sorry I-” the look on her face was enough to quiet Peter and still his racing heart. It wasn’t irritable or embarrassed or awkward. It was perfectly content and maybe a little bit entertained. She would have expected nothing less from Peter and found he rose to the title of dorkiest, sweetest boyfriend ever quite well in that particular moment.

So that time she was the one to pull out her wallet, brushing off Peter’s objections with a light squeeze of his hand and easygoing mention of the new cafe opened down the street. With a rueful chuckle Peter followed her to the door, giving one last nod to the brightly colored kids menu displayed overhead.

“You mean you’re sure you don’t want the five dollar family pizza?”

In sickness and in health

“Peter,” she croaked whiningly, burying further under the quilts piled atop her bed while the brunett beside it desperately tried to get her to wake without drop kicking him with a Thor slipper still on her foot.

“C'mon babe, you gotta take your antibiotic,” he gingerly tried to peel back the duvet, being greeted with her mess of a self glaring at him through half lidded eyes and a curtain of her hair she couldn’t be bothered to push back. Huffing irritably, she heaved herself into a sitting position and leant against the headboard for support, combing through her bird’s nest of an updo that had been tossed about in her sleep.

Peter patiently reached over to the nightstand and held out a small glass along with her medications in each hand, helping to hold up the cup when necessary since her grip was even shakier than usual. She wiped the corner of her lip groggily, staring at Peter with that same look she always had when he was being far too sweet with her and she wanted to be mad but couldn’t bring herself to put the energy into it.

“You’re not supposed to be here,” She grumbled, leaning forward to rest her head on his shoulder nonetheless. She felt it shake slightly with a short laugh,his fingertips running through her hair to carefully thread through the knots she had missed.

Last time she’d been awake, it was right after school and Peter had come bustling in with her favorite movies and tea bags in tow. Even after several minutes of trying to convince him to go home and preserve his health while he could, Peter obviously wasn’t going to budge. So she had grudgingly flopped back onto her mattress and made small talk with him until her pills kicked in and made her a drowsy, incoherent mess. And of course Peter couldn’t take her seriously when she had demanded he not be here when she wake up; wagging her finger in the air with a cheek squished against her pillow and a well loved Spider-Man plushie in the crook of her arm.

“You mean you aren’t glad to see me?” He teased lightly, smoothing his hand down from the back of her neck to the base of her spine and rubbing soothing patterns into it. Her indignant huff was enough of an answer to have Peter grinning.

“Don’t be stupid,” she began to play with his fingers like a small child, eventually lacing them with her own. “'Course I’m happy to see you.” Her words were still a bit slurred from sleep, and halfway muffled by the fabric of Peter’s hoodie. So he had a difficult time continuing to contain his laughter when she pressed a small, clumsy kiss to the neckline of his t-shirt and carelessly dropped back onto the bed with a pitiful sigh.

“S'there anything I can do for you, beautiful?” He hummed, trying to brush away the strands of her hair that had strewn back across her face when she flopped into the comfort of her pillows. She let out a dry snicker at his choice of words.

“Yeah,I’m sure i’m looking stunning at the moment,” her words were dripping in sarcasm but the way she leans into Peter’s touch was all too genuine for him to even think of rolling his eyes. Instead he nodded as if the irony wasn’t even present in her tone, eyes full of adoration as he ran a thumb over her cheek. She laughed again at this, but the sound is a bit gentler, a bit more true. “Thank you Peter,” she sighed, drawing his hand down from her face and to clasp with her own.

Only moments later, an older woman with worry and smile lines alike came scurrying into the room, face warming into a smile at the sight laid out in her daughter’s bedroom while she sets down her bags. “Thank you so much, Peter. I don’t know how you get her to be so sweet with you. Usually by now I would have been kicked out to the living room,” the woman teased, coming to kiss her daughter’s forehead and beam at the boy that had managed to tame her obstinate spirit.

“Not a problem at all,” Peter exchanged a genuine smile with the both of them before her mother began rambling about how late it had gotten and if Peter needed a ride home. “No,no,it’s alright. My car’s out front. But are you sure I don’t need to stay?if you’ve still got work I can keep this one company,” He nudged her thigh with a playful grin, only getting a roll of her tired eyes in response as she tugged the blankets back up to her chin.

“Oh don’t worry about it,sweetie.I think I can handle it from here,” The older woman assured Peter, ushering him up and to the door so he wouldn’t be getting home at too ungodly of an hour. But just as the pair of them got to the door and Peter blew a dramatic kiss goodbye, Her voice rose from the blankets in a final solemn request.

“Peter,” the boy whipped around so fast he would probably have whiplash for the next week, brows raised and feet ready to head wherever she required. But she only reached out her hands from beneath the duvet, making a childish grabbing motion that spread a grin onto Peter’s lips immediately.

“Leave the hoodie,”

“Till death do us part”

Peter didn’t even have the thought to wait until he was permitted to kiss his wife. They were already in each other’s arms, glossy eyed and smiling a bit too hard for their lips to meet properly. There was laughter and cheering and quite possibly a clap of thunder a few miles away, even though the sky was crystal clear and void of a single rain cloud.

They share a small snicker as they part, eyes wide with wonder and surprise that even the godly branch of Peter’s family had made the effort to celebrate on such an important day. But it seemed that the lord of thunder wasn’t the only one present, but his brother as well. At least, that’s who Peter blames when he sent the pair of them tripping down the stair steps on the way out, headed towards their new life together with hearty laughter and curved lipped kisses, just as predicted.

“Like, from Harry Potter?” She let out a soft laugh at his inquiry, the sound making Peter’s heart thump a bit faster and his lips press together in a sheepish smile. It was a nice sound to hear. Mellow, sincere, and just bubbly enough to coax a small, breathless snicker from himself as well.

He noticed just before she ducked her head down in a bashful smile that her eyes seemed to glint with a different kind of light than they did during the hustle and bustle of the school days. A bit more real,a bit more raw. He supposed something about having the whole of the galaxy mapped out before you did that to a person. But maybe he just saw the reflection of Canopus in the sea of her irises.

Sure, her heart would skip a beat nearly every time she caught Peter staring at her after she’d come back from peering through the telescope. And she felt the world wobble beneath her feet a bit when his hand brushed against hers while adjusting the focus. But at the moment they were simply a pair of over-enthusiastic teens gawking at the intricately woven constellations hung up well above the light pollution of a never-sleeping city.

“Exactly,” She lifts her head back up, a faint ghost of a smile still visible in the curve of her cheeks. “It’s the brightest one we’ve found yet. Just along Orion’s belt,” she traces out the contours of the asterism, fixating once again on the star in question.

Peter nods, unable to keep the smile from his face as she continues to muse about the various shapes, sizes, and stories drawn across the night sky. She looked nothing short of breathtaking like this. Peter couldn’t get enough of the wonderstruck brilliance that she radiated while explaining every small detail and facet of the celestial wonders beheld to him. He never dreamt he’d be close enough to a star to feel the nuclear fusion tingling at his fingertips.

from this day forward

She had promised herself she wouldn’t. She knew it was ridiculous and completely naive of her to be indulging in ideas like that. She knew better and she’d be lying if she said it wasn’t getting rather irritating trying to run from what she felt for Peter.

She hadn’t seen it coming. It was supposed to be just another normal day. Normal being a relative term considering her life had been turned upside down since that first night with Peter at the observatory almost seven months ago.

It was impossibly wonderful and painfully new for her. Having somebody as thoughtful, understanding, and genuine as Peter wasn’t something she was used to. And while he was nothing short of amazing to her, and she adored every minute she got to spend with him-there was a sense of unshakable vulnerability that she still had yet to fully accept.

So when he texted her amidst the hectic buzz of her Monday morning with a new picture of that dawn’s sunrise-she found herself typing out a response without a second thought. The grin was still on her face as she pressed send, not even realizing that she’d just taken a massive leap and would soon be feeling the effects of a nosedive into the deep end.

“Oh my god,” she breathed,heart skipping a beat as she read the text a second, third, and fourth time.

‘God,I love you,Parker,’

“Shit, Shit, Shit,” she muttered under her breath, tugging a hand through her barely brushed mass of bedhead and shoving the phone across the kitchen counter before beginning to pace wildly about the room. Her stomach was churning and head was spinning with all the possibilities of how this could end- none of them being positive of course.

After what feels like ages of stumbling about the chilled tile, she braved a glance back at her phone.Her heart dropped straight to her socks.

'Read: 6:15’

She felt her throat begin to close up and top row of teeth come down harshly on her bottom lip, gnawing vainly to try and diffuse the terror spreading through her veins like ice water. Just when she thought she might be sick from the wait, a loud crash from her front balcony sends the young girl straight into a whole other panic.

Her breath hitched and eyes went wide,fixating on the figure strewn across the concrete floor, leg entangled in a lawn chair and kicking helplessly to try and escape it.

“What the fu-” she can’t finish her sentence before she’s at the pair of glass doors and Peter’s flushed face lifted to meet her gaze, still lowered onto the floor where he’s splayed out and ensnared by her mother’s favorite lounging seat. Finally,he managed to struggle free from the confines and onto his feet, chest heaving and hair still fluffed about in a clearly slept on fashion.

“Peter,” She exclaimed, absolutely awestruck as she pulled back the door to stare at him with parted lips and furrowed brows. “How did you even get here I live two blocks away-” Peter didn’t even let her finish the sentence before letting his backpack slip off his shoulders and feet carry him straight to her incredulous person.

She didn’t have the time to register him lifting his hands to cup her face before their lips had already met, his own gentle yet insistent as he held her as close as possible. He could hear both of their hearts hammering against the cage of their ribs and feel her feather light touches shock his skin like lightning bolts. He was so caught up in the moment that he almost forgot to breathe until his lungs began to burn.

Nothing but the heavy gasps of the pair filled the space between them for a moment, eyes wide and searching eachother’s for any sign of just what the hell might be going on. “I wanted to tell you in person,” he murmured, cheeks burning and hands lowering back to her own. They were shaking furiously as he took hold of her palms, which began to tremble as well as soon as they connected.

“What?” She asked, completely dumbfounded and having forgotten just what she was so distraught about as soon as Peter had kissed her. He pressed his lips together like he always did when he’s anxious,working the bottom one between his teeth as Peter attempted to pluck up the courage to get the words past the hollow of his throat.

“I,” He inhaled, running his thumbs over the backs of her knuckles in a desperate effort to ground himself. “I love you too,” his eyes only dare lift up to hers for a moment, flickering around her face to try and gather any sign of recognition that he could. When her eyes start to gloss over, he thinks the worst.

“Oh god I didn’t mean to-” She practically throws herself onto him, arms wrapping around his neck as she pulls his frame flush against her own. Peter can feel her shoulders shake with a small, watered down laugh, hands gripping the fabric of his hoodie like a lifeline. He quickly wraps his arms around her middle to return the gesture. Peter’s heart began to even out its pace, and they both just stood there for a moment, trying to figure out how they got so lucky.

She hadn’t been sure before. Whether things with Peter would work or not. Whether she could keep counting the days until things inevitably crashed and burned for the pair of them. But at the moment, all she needed was his arms round her waist and nose against her temple, soft utterances of the phrase passing freely between the both of them.

When she lifted her head from his shoulder, her eyes catch on the deep red and blue fabric spilling from the top of Peter’s backpack, which still laid carelessly dropped on her balcony. She pulled back a moment,brows furrowed and lips curled just the slightest. “Peter?” She fought down a light laugh, her boyfriend stirring from his moonstruck daze only to appreciate her smile.

“Yeah?”

“Why do you have a morphsuit in your backpack?”

for better or for worse

“Do you even care?” the words clawed past the minuscule passage of her throat and tore through her teeth like bullets from the barrel of a gun. They hit Peter head on. Straight in the hollow of his chest where he presumed his heart was intended to reside. But at the moment it had just felt like somebody replaced it with a bundle of barbed wire; prodding and poking at all the bruises littered across his chest and scraping the sides of his lungs so air could only leak out like that from a punctured balloon.

The wounds hidden beneath this sweatshirt felt measly in comparison to seeing her like that. All pursed lips and red rimmed eyes. Her whitened knuckles were curled around the massive binder clutched close to her chest, where he was meant to be. Instead it felt like they were universes apart, Peter just now coming to the realization that there was no oxygen in the vast emptiness of space.

He sputtered, absolutely perturbed that she would even ask a question like that. Of course he cared. He cared so much that he felt he might burst at the seams some days. But maybe today it was more than a feeling. He could sense himself crumbling as he struggled to get the words out, falling short when her eyes began to water. “What do you mean?!Of course I care about you-”

“Not me-this isn’t about me,Peter,” she said sharply, words having an effect all too similar to the shrapnel that had gotten lodged in his stomach the night before. “This is about you- you throwing yourself into danger at the smallest sign of it and not even thinking about what could happen. You could have-” her voice was the one to fail her that time, splintering beneath the pressure in her lungs and dropping to the scuffed tile floor in shards.

For the first time since he’d met her, the thought crosses Peter’s mind that maybe it would have been better if he hadn’t.

for richer or for poorer

“Peter, oh my god I was just kidding you really don’t have to,” she could barely contain her giggles as she braced one hand on his hunched shoulder and the other on the smudged glass of the arcade game window. Peter found this all the more distracting, and only slightly irritating since her laugh and gentle touch threw off his skill completely. So of course, whenever he tilted his head to share a lopsided smile with her, the machine instantly whirred with a sickenly familiar sound to remind him he’d run out of time.

His face fell into a defeated frown, her own still aglow in the neon lights as she tried to coax him to try out another game with her. But Peter Parker was a stubborn little shit when it came to making his girlfriend happy. So if he had to take out a loan to get that damn Spider-Man plushie, you’d best believe he would.

Without a single moment’s hesitation, Peter took her hand in his and dragged the pair of them back to the token machine with a twenty curled in his other palm. “Peter,” she tried to suppress her laughter long enough to get him to reconsider spending his life savings on a rigged claw machine. Needless to say-it did not work.

Within thirty seconds they were practically sprinting back across the funky printed carpet to the games, since Peter was completely sure that if they waited a moment longer that somebody would come steal that toy along with his girlfriend as well.

Eleven tries and eleven defeats later, she finally managed to get Peter to step away from his newfound nemesis and quite possibly the toughest criminal he’d faced in all of Queens. “Why don’t you let me give it a try?” She wrapped her arms around his waist, peering over his shoulder into the pile of stuffed animals with an amused smirk still digging into her cheeks. With a sheepish smile, Peter plucked his last pair of tokens from his pocket. He slipped them into the coin slot before swapping positions with her and settling one of his hands atop hers that had gripped the toggle and button.

“You don’t get to take the credit for my win just because you held my hand,Parker,” She taunted lightly, trying not to let the feeling on his chin rested atop her head and warm chest pressed against her back get the best of her. She almost dropped the claw accidentally when it rumbled with a soft chuckle, Peter watching on eagerly as she guided it to the perfect spot.

“yes! oh my god!” She fell back into his grip with a grin on her face and laughter bubbling from her lungs. Peter stared in complete shock as the claw dropped the small plush down the hatch with supernatural ease. He reluctantly released her from his arms to let her crouch down and collect the prize, lips parted and eyes the size of saucers.

“I can’t believe that,” Peter shook his head lightly, still smiling enough to let her know she hadn’t completely demolished his pride with her immaculate claw machine prowess. She just continued to laugh, using one hand to hold her newest treasure and the other to link with Peter’s.

“You ready for lunch?Unless you went broke trying to free Spider-Man Junior here, that is,” her eyes twinkled and Peter flushed lightly, the shade deepening when he fished through his pockets and came up empty. “Oh my god you actually did,” she declared, snickering helplessly as she fell into Peter and kissed his heated cheek affectionately while he fumbled for an explanation.

“I’m so sorry I-” the look on her face was enough to quiet Peter and still his racing heart. It wasn’t irritable or embarrassed or awkward. It was perfectly content and maybe a little bit entertained. She would have expected nothing less from Peter and found he rose to the title of dorkiest, sweetest boyfriend ever quite well in that particular moment.

So that time she was the one to pull out her wallet, brushing off Peter’s objections with a light squeeze of his hand and easygoing mention of the new cafe opened down the street. With a rueful chuckle Peter followed her to the door, giving one last nod to the brightly colored kids menu displayed overhead.

“You mean you’re sure you don’t want the five dollar family pizza?”

In sickness and in health

“Peter,” she croaked whiningly, burying further under the quilts piled atop her bed while the brunett beside it desperately tried to get her to wake without drop kicking him with a Thor slipper still on her foot.

“C'mon babe, you gotta take your antibiotic,” he gingerly tried to peel back the duvet, being greeted with her mess of a self glaring at him through half lidded eyes and a curtain of her hair she couldn’t be bothered to push back. Huffing irritably, she heaved herself into a sitting position and leant against the headboard for support, combing through her bird’s nest of an updo that had been tossed about in her sleep.

Peter patiently reached over to the nightstand and held out a small glass along with her medications in each hand, helping to hold up the cup when necessary since her grip was even shakier than usual. She wiped the corner of her lip groggily, staring at Peter with that same look she always had when he was being far too sweet with her and she wanted to be mad but couldn’t bring herself to put the energy into it.

“You’re not supposed to be here,” She grumbled, leaning forward to rest her head on his shoulder nonetheless. She felt it shake slightly with a short laugh,his fingertips running through her hair to carefully thread through the knots she had missed.

Last time she’d been awake, it was right after school and Peter had come bustling in with her favorite movies and tea bags in tow. Even after several minutes of trying to convince him to go home and preserve his health while he could, Peter obviously wasn’t going to budge. So she had grudgingly flopped back onto her mattress and made small talk with him until her pills kicked in and made her a drowsy, incoherent mess. And of course Peter couldn’t take her seriously when she had demanded he not be here when she wake up; wagging her finger in the air with a cheek squished against her pillow and a well loved Spider-Man plushie in the crook of her arm.

“You mean you aren’t glad to see me?” He teased lightly, smoothing his hand down from the back of her neck to the base of her spine and rubbing soothing patterns into it. Her indignant huff was enough of an answer to have Peter grinning.

“Don’t be stupid,” she began to play with his fingers like a small child, eventually lacing them with her own. “'Course I’m happy to see you.” Her words were still a bit slurred from sleep, and halfway muffled by the fabric of Peter’s hoodie. So he had a difficult time continuing to contain his laughter when she pressed a small, clumsy kiss to the neckline of his t-shirt and carelessly dropped back onto the bed with a pitiful sigh.

“S'there anything I can do for you, beautiful?” He hummed, trying to brush away the strands of her hair that had strewn back across her face when she flopped into the comfort of her pillows. She let out a dry snicker at his choice of words.

“Yeah,I’m sure i’m looking stunning at the moment,” her words were dripping in sarcasm but the way she leans into Peter’s touch was all too genuine for him to even think of rolling his eyes. Instead he nodded as if the irony wasn’t even present in her tone, eyes full of adoration as he ran a thumb over her cheek. She laughed again at this, but the sound is a bit gentler, a bit more true. “Thank you Peter,” she sighed, drawing his hand down from her face and to clasp with her own.

Only moments later, an older woman with worry and smile lines alike came scurrying into the room, face warming into a smile at the sight laid out in her daughter’s bedroom while she sets down her bags. “Thank you so much, Peter. I don’t know how you get her to be so sweet with you. Usually by now I would have been kicked out to the living room,” the woman teased, coming to kiss her daughter’s forehead and beam at the boy that had managed to tame her obstinate spirit.

“Not a problem at all,” Peter exchanged a genuine smile with the both of them before her mother began rambling about how late it had gotten and if Peter needed a ride home. “No,no,it’s alright. My car’s out front. But are you sure I don’t need to stay?if you’ve still got work I can keep this one company,” He nudged her thigh with a playful grin, only getting a roll of her tired eyes in response as she tugged the blankets back up to her chin.

“Oh don’t worry about it,sweetie.I think I can handle it from here,” The older woman assured Peter, ushering him up and to the door so he wouldn’t be getting home at too ungodly of an hour. But just as the pair of them got to the door and Peter blew a dramatic kiss goodbye, Her voice rose from the blankets in a final solemn request.

“Peter,” the boy whipped around so fast he would probably have whiplash for the next week, brows raised and feet ready to head wherever she required. But she only reached out her hands from beneath the duvet, making a childish grabbing motion that spread a grin onto Peter’s lips immediately.

“Leave the hoodie,”

“Till death do us part”

Peter didn’t even have the thought to wait until he was permitted to kiss his wife. They were already in each other’s arms, glossy eyed and smiling a bit too hard for their lips to meet properly. There was laughter and cheering and quite possibly a clap of thunder a few miles away, even though the sky was crystal clear and void of a single rain cloud.

They share a small snicker as they part, eyes wide with wonder and surprise that even the godly branch of Peter’s family had made the effort to celebrate on such an important day. But it seemed that the lord of thunder wasn’t the only one present, but his brother as well. At least, that’s who Peter blames when he sent the pair of them tripping down the stair steps on the way out, headed towards their new life together with hearty laughter and curved lipped kisses, just as predicted.

I take you

Peter had never, in his wildest, most surreal dreams imagined being here today. With the pristine light of early morning rays filtering through ornately designed windows, arcing above their heads and set in aged but intricately carved stone. A sea of familiar, beaming faces sitting in the pews. Composed of not-quite blood relatives but family all the same; all of them alight with inexplicable joy on a day nearly everyone had been betting on since Peter’s sophomore year at Midtown when he bumped into the best thing to ever happen to him-and spilled her physics homework all over the hall.

He was nervous, to say the least. His clammy palms and bouncing heels were proof enough. Even Ned was beginning to get a bit exasperated at how frequently Peter would ask the time or try to run a hand through his carefully done hair,promptly ruining all the hard work May had done that morning to try and tame his wild curls.

Peter knew in his deepest sense that things would be alright. Even if he stuttered the entire way through his vows, and dropped the ring and fumbled over the steps down the stairs. At the end of it all they would still be lovesick messes and exchange breathless laughter between curved-lip kisses.

She almost dropped the claw accidentally when it rumbled with a soft chuckle, Peter watching on eagerly as she guided it to the perfect spot.

“yes! oh my god!” She fell back into his grip with a grin on her face and laughter bubbling from her lungs. Peter stared in complete shock as the claw dropped the small plush down the hatch with supernatural ease. He reluctantly released her from his arms to let her crouch down and collect the prize, lips parted and eyes the size of saucers.

“I can’t believe that,” Peter shook his head lightly, still smiling enough to let her know she hadn’t completely demolished his pride with her immaculate claw machine prowess. She just continued to laugh, using one hand to hold her newest treasure and the other to link with Peter’s.

“You ready for lunch?Unless you went broke trying to free Spider-Man Junior here, that is,” her eyes twinkled and Peter flushed lightly, the shade deepening when he fished through his pockets and came up empty. “Oh my god you actually did,” she declared, snickering helplessly as she fell into Peter and kissed his heated cheek affectionately while he fumbled for an explanation.

“I’m so sorry I-” the look on her face was enough to quiet Peter and still his racing heart. It wasn’t irritable or embarrassed or awkward. It was perfectly content and maybe a little bit entertained. She would have expected nothing less from Peter and found he rose to the title of dorkiest, sweetest boyfriend ever quite well in that particular moment.

So that time she was the one to pull out her wallet, brushing off Peter’s objections with a light squeeze of his hand and easygoing mention of the new cafe opened down the street. With a rueful chuckle Peter followed her to the door, giving one last nod to the brightly colored kids menu displayed overhead.

“You mean you’re sure you don’t want the five dollar family pizza?”

In sickness and in health

“Peter,” she croaked whiningly, burying further under the quilts piled atop her bed while the brunett beside it desperately tried to get her to wake without drop kicking him with a Thor slipper still on her foot.

“C'mon babe, you gotta take your antibiotic,” he gingerly tried to peel back the duvet, being greeted with her mess of a self glaring at him through half lidded eyes and a curtain of her hair she couldn’t be bothered to push back. Huffing irritably, she heaved herself into a sitting position and leant against the headboard for support, combing through her bird’s nest of an updo that had been tossed about in her sleep.

Peter patiently reached over to the nightstand and held out a small glass along with her medications in each hand, helping to hold up the cup when necessary since her grip was even shakier than usual. She wiped the corner of her lip groggily, staring at Peter with that same look she always had when he was being far too sweet with her and she wanted to be mad but couldn’t bring herself to put the energy into it.

“You’re not supposed to be here,” She grumbled, leaning forward to rest her head on his shoulder nonetheless. She felt it shake slightly with a short laugh,his fingertips running through her hair to carefully thread through the knots she had missed.

Last time she’d been awake, it was right after school and Peter had come bustling in with her favorite movies and tea bags in tow. Even after several minutes of trying to convince him to go home and preserve his health while he could, Peter obviously wasn’t going to budge. So she had grudgingly flopped back onto her mattress and made small talk with him until her pills kicked in and made her a drowsy, incoherent mess. And of course Peter couldn’t take her seriously when she had demanded he not be here when she wake up; wagging her finger in the air with a cheek squished against her pillow and a well loved Spider-Man plushie in the crook of her arm.

“You mean you aren’t glad to see me?” He teased lightly, smoothing his hand down from the back of her neck to the base of her spine and rubbing soothing patterns into it. Her indignant huff was enough of an answer to have Peter grinning.

“Don’t be stupid,” she began to play with his fingers like a small child, eventually lacing them with her own. “'Course I’m happy to see you.” Her words were still a bit slurred from sleep, and halfway muffled by the fabric of Peter’s hoodie. So he had a difficult time continuing to contain his laughter when she pressed a small, clumsy kiss to the neckline of his t-shirt and carelessly dropped back onto the bed with a pitiful sigh.

“S'there anything I can do for you, beautiful?” He hummed, trying to brush away the strands of her hair that had strewn back across her face when she flopped into the comfort of her pillows. She let out a dry snicker at his choice of words.

“Yeah,I’m sure i’m looking stunning at the moment,” her words were dripping in sarcasm but the way she leans into Peter’s touch was all too genuine for him to even think of rolling his eyes. Instead he nodded as if the irony wasn’t even present in her tone, eyes full of adoration as he ran a thumb over her cheek. She laughed again at this, but the sound is a bit gentler, a bit more true. “Thank you Peter,” she sighed, drawing his hand down from her face and to clasp with her own.

Only moments later, an older woman with worry and smile lines alike came scurrying into the room, face warming into a smile at the sight laid out in her daughter’s bedroom while she sets down her bags. “Thank you so much, Peter. I don’t know how you get her to be so sweet with you. Usually by now I would have been kicked out to the living room,” the woman teased, coming to kiss her daughter’s forehead and beam at the boy that had managed to tame her obstinate spirit.

“Not a problem at all,” Peter exchanged a genuine smile with the both of them before her mother began rambling about how late it had gotten and if Peter needed a ride home. “No,no,it’s alright. My car’s out front. But are you sure I don’t need to stay?if you’ve still got work I can keep this one company,” He nudged her thigh with a playful grin, only getting a roll of her tired eyes in response as she tugged the blankets back up to her chin.

“Oh don’t worry about it,sweetie.I think I can handle it from here,” The older woman assured Peter, ushering him up and to the door so he wouldn’t be getting home at too ungodly of an hour. But just as the pair of them got to the door and Peter blew a dramatic kiss goodbye, Her voice rose from the blankets in a final solemn request.

“Peter,” the boy whipped around so fast he would probably have whiplash for the next week, brows raised and feet ready to head wherever she required. But she only reached out her hands from beneath the duvet, making a childish grabbing motion that spread a grin onto Peter’s lips immediately.

“Leave the hoodie,”

“Till death do us part”

Peter didn’t even have the thought to wait until he was permitted to kiss his wife. They were already in each other’s arms, glossy eyed and smiling a bit too hard for their lips to meet properly. There was laughter and cheering and quite possibly a clap of thunder a few miles away, even though the sky was crystal clear and void of a single rain cloud.

They share a small snicker as they part, eyes wide with wonder and surprise that even the godly branch of Peter’s family had made the effort to celebrate on such an important day. But it seemed that the lord of thunder wasn’t the only one present, but his brother as well. At least, that’s who Peter blames when he sent the pair of them tripping down the stair steps on the way out, headed towards their new life together with hearty laughter and curved lipped kisses, just as predicted.

At the end of it all they would still be lovesick messes and exchange breathless laughter between curved-lip kisses.”

warnings : angst, mentions of injuries, a little language? (the rest is fluff I promise)

I take you

Peter had never, in his wildest, most surreal dreams imagined being here today. With the pristine light of early morning rays filtering through ornately designed windows, arcing above their heads and set in aged but intricately carved stone. A sea of familiar, beaming faces sitting in the pews. Composed of not-quite blood relatives but family all the same; all of them alight with inexplicable joy on a day nearly everyone had been betting on since Peter’s sophomore year at Midtown when he bumped into the best thing to ever happen to him-and spilled her physics homework all over the hall.

He was nervous, to say the least. His clammy palms and bouncing heels were proof enough. Even Ned was beginning to get a bit exasperated at how frequently Peter would ask the time or try to run a hand through his carefully done hair,promptly ruining all the hard work May had done that morning to try and tame his wild curls.

Peter knew in his deepest sense that things would be alright. Even if he stuttered the entire way through his vows, and dropped the ring and fumbled over the steps down the stairs. At the end of it all they would still be lovesick messes and exchange breathless laughter between curved-lip kisses.

That didn’t stop him from nearly jumping out of his tux when the massive chapel doors heave open with a labored groan. The sound seems to reverberate through the hollows of his lungs, filling them to the brim with a familiar too-full ache. That’s how he always feels when she’s around. Too full. As if there’s only so much space in his body available to contain the amount of love and adoration he holds for her. Something so immeasurable and indescribable couldn’t so easily be held in the confines of Peter’s heart.

So it presses against the walls of his lungs and curves of his ribs, making his jaw go slack and eyes water when they land on her figure at the foot of the walkway. He can barely get enough oxygen in his lungs to laugh at himself, feeling a bit unsteady on his own two feet as he drinks in the image of her donned in white and glowing with the radiance of-

to have and to hold

“Sirius,” she states quietly, Peter’s gaze following the tip of her finger to the pinprick of light only fully visible through the massive telescope they’d both been stealing glances from (along with a few directed towards each other) throughout the night.

“Like, from Harry Potter?” She let out a soft laugh at his inquiry, the sound making Peter’s heart thump a bit faster and his lips press together in a sheepish smile. It was a nice sound to hear. Mellow, sincere, and just bubbly enough to coax a small, breathless snicker from himself as well.

He noticed just before she ducked her head down in a bashful smile that her eyes seemed to glint with a different kind of light than they did during the hustle and bustle of the school days. A bit more real,a bit more raw. He supposed something about having the whole of the galaxy mapped out before you did that to a person. But maybe he just saw the reflection of Canopus in the sea of her irises.

Sure, her heart would skip a beat nearly every time she caught Peter staring at her after she’d come back from peering through the telescope. And she felt the world wobble beneath her feet a bit when his hand brushed against hers while adjusting the focus. But at the moment they were simply a pair of over-enthusiastic teens gawking at the intricately woven constellations hung up well above the light pollution of a never-sleeping city.

“Exactly,” She lifts her head back up, a faint ghost of a smile still visible in the curve of her cheeks. “It’s the brightest one we’ve found yet. Just along Orion’s belt,” she traces out the contours of the asterism, fixating once again on the star in question.

Peter nods, unable to keep the smile from his face as she continues to muse about the various shapes, sizes, and stories drawn across the night sky. She looked nothing short of breathtaking like this. Peter couldn’t get enough of the wonderstruck brilliance that she radiated while explaining every small detail and facet of the celestial wonders beheld to him. He never dreamt he’d be close enough to a star to feel the nuclear fusion tingling at his fingertips.

from this day forward

She had promised herself she wouldn’t. She knew it was ridiculous and completely naive of her to be indulging in ideas like that. She knew better and she’d be lying if she said it wasn’t getting rather irritating trying to run from what she felt for Peter.

She hadn’t seen it coming. It was supposed to be just another normal day. Normal being a relative term considering her life had been turned upside down since that first night with Peter at the observatory almost seven months ago.

It was impossibly wonderful and painfully new for her. Having somebody as thoughtful, understanding, and genuine as Peter wasn’t something she was used to. And while he was nothing short of amazing to her, and she adored every minute she got to spend with him-there was a sense of unshakable vulnerability that she still had yet to fully accept.

So when he texted her amidst the hectic buzz of her Monday morning with a new picture of that dawn’s sunrise-she found herself typing out a response without a second thought. The grin was still on her face as she pressed send, not even realizing that she’d just taken a massive leap and would soon be feeling the effects of a nosedive into the deep end.

“Oh my god,” she breathed,heart skipping a beat as she read the text a second, third, and fourth time.

‘God,I love you,Parker,’

“Shit, Shit, Shit,” she muttered under her breath, tugging a hand through her barely brushed mass of bedhead and shoving the phone across the kitchen counter before beginning to pace wildly about the room. Her stomach was churning and head was spinning with all the possibilities of how this could end- none of them being positive of course.

After what feels like ages of stumbling about the chilled tile, she braved a glance back at her phone.Her heart dropped straight to her socks.

'Read: 6:15’

She felt her throat begin to close up and top row of teeth come down harshly on her bottom lip, gnawing vainly to try and diffuse the terror spreading through her veins like ice water. Just when she thought she might be sick from the wait, a loud crash from her front balcony sends the young girl straight into a whole other panic.

Her breath hitched and eyes went wide,fixating on the figure strewn across the concrete floor, leg entangled in a lawn chair and kicking helplessly to try and escape it.

“What the fu-” she can’t finish her sentence before she’s at the pair of glass doors and Peter’s flushed face lifted to meet her gaze, still lowered onto the floor where he’s splayed out and ensnared by her mother’s favorite lounging seat. Finally,he managed to struggle free from the confines and onto his feet, chest heaving and hair still fluffed about in a clearly slept on fashion.

“Peter,” She exclaimed, absolutely awestruck as she pulled back the door to stare at him with parted lips and furrowed brows. “How did you even get here I live two blocks away-” Peter didn’t even let her finish the sentence before letting his backpack slip off his shoulders and feet carry him straight to her incredulous person.

She didn’t have the time to register him lifting his hands to cup her face before their lips had already met, his own gentle yet insistent as he held her as close as possible. He could hear both of their hearts hammering against the cage of their ribs and feel her feather light touches shock his skin like lightning bolts. He was so caught up in the moment that he almost forgot to breathe until his lungs began to burn.

Nothing but the heavy gasps of the pair filled the space between them for a moment, eyes wide and searching eachother’s for any sign of just what the hell might be going on. “I wanted to tell you in person,” he murmured, cheeks burning and hands lowering back to her own. They were shaking furiously as he took hold of her palms, which began to tremble as well as soon as they connected.

“What?” She asked, completely dumbfounded and having forgotten just what she was so distraught about as soon as Peter had kissed her. He pressed his lips together like he always did when he’s anxious,working the bottom one between his teeth as Peter attempted to pluck up the courage to get the words past the hollow of his throat.

“I,” He inhaled, running his thumbs over the backs of her knuckles in a desperate effort to ground himself. “I love you too,” his eyes only dare lift up to hers for a moment, flickering around her face to try and gather any sign of recognition that he could. When her eyes start to gloss over, he thinks the worst.

“Oh god I didn’t mean to-” She practically throws herself onto him, arms wrapping around his neck as she pulls his frame flush against her own. Peter can feel her shoulders shake with a small, watered down laugh, hands gripping the fabric of his hoodie like a lifeline. He quickly wraps his arms around her middle to return the gesture. Peter’s heart began to even out its pace, and they both just stood there for a moment, trying to figure out how they got so lucky.

She hadn’t been sure before. Whether things with Peter would work or not. Whether she could keep counting the days until things inevitably crashed and burned for the pair of them. But at the moment, all she needed was his arms round her waist and nose against her temple, soft utterances of the phrase passing freely between the both of them.

When she lifted her head from his shoulder, her eyes catch on the deep red and blue fabric spilling from the top of Peter’s backpack, which still laid carelessly dropped on her balcony. She pulled back a moment,brows furrowed and lips curled just the slightest. “Peter?” She fought down a light laugh, her boyfriend stirring from his moonstruck daze only to appreciate her smile.

“Yeah?”

“Why do you have a morphsuit in your backpack?”

for better or for worse

“Do you even care?” the words clawed past the minuscule passage of her throat and tore through her teeth like bullets from the barrel of a gun. They hit Peter head on. Straight in the hollow of his chest where he presumed his heart was intended to reside. But at the moment it had just felt like somebody replaced it with a bundle of barbed wire; prodding and poking at all the bruises littered across his chest and scraping the sides of his lungs so air could only leak out like that from a punctured balloon.

The wounds hidden beneath this sweatshirt felt measly in comparison to seeing her like that. All pursed lips and red rimmed eyes. Her whitened knuckles were curled around the massive binder clutched close to her chest, where he was meant to be. Instead it felt like they were universes apart, Peter just now coming to the realization that there was no oxygen in the vast emptiness of space.

He sputtered, absolutely perturbed that she would even ask a question like that. Of course he cared. He cared so much that he felt he might burst at the seams some days. But maybe today it was more than a feeling. He could sense himself crumbling as he struggled to get the words out, falling short when her eyes began to water. “What do you mean?!Of course I care about you-”

“Not me-this isn’t about me,Peter,” she said sharply, words having an effect all too similar to the shrapnel that had gotten lodged in his stomach the night before. “This is about you- you throwing yourself into danger at the smallest sign of it and not even thinking about what could happen. You could have-” her voice was the one to fail her that time, splintering beneath the pressure in her lungs and dropping to the scuffed tile floor in shards.

For the first time since he’d met her, the thought crosses Peter’s mind that maybe it would have been better if he hadn’t.

for richer or for poorer

“Peter, oh my god I was just kidding you really don’t have to,” she could barely contain her giggles as she braced one hand on his hunched shoulder and the other on the smudged glass of the arcade game window. So of course, whenever he tilted his head to share a lopsided smile with her, the machine instantly whirred with a sickenly familiar sound to remind him he’d run out of time.

His face fell into a defeated frown, her own still aglow in the neon lights as she tried to coax him to try out another game with her. Without a single moment’s hesitation, Peter took her hand in his and dragged the pair of them back to the token machine with a twenty curled in his other palm. “Peter,” she tried to suppress her laughter long enough to get him to reconsider spending his life savings on a rigged claw machine. body:
Peter: There is to be no more swearing in this household!
Tony: Oh, poop.
Peter, giggling: He calls his shit poop!
Peter: Oh no.

summary: Castle on a Cloud
title: Castle on a Cloud
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2NMCvck

by CaptainStarSong

“How the Hell am I supposed to help some kid when half the time my own life is crashing and burning,” Tony asked, incredulous that Fury was thinking that he could possibly take care of some little boy that he didn’t even know. There was a reason why Tony’s life was practically always falling a part, why the closest people around him either died or left him. It wouldn’t be fair to bring some kid into the mix of his crazy life, especially after Afghanistan.

Fury took a deep breath as looked at Tony with a hint of pity. “Because, Tony, his name is Peter and he’s your son.”

Or in which SHIELD finds a young and hurt Peter after raiding a HYDRA base, and Tony must learn how to become the father Peter needs.
